history.text: I'll watch just about anything with either Tom Hanks or Leo DiCaprio.
Me too. I really liked this movie as I recall.
I didn't realize that it did so well on Rotten Tomatoes
I liked it, but I don't think it deserved a 96% rating.
Does that math even work out? 7.9 out of ten doesn't seem like it would be a 96%. You would think that would be a 79$
79%, rather.
Do you usually watch movies like this?
Around the time that this movie came out, I watched almost everything that came out. I was a college kid with too much time on my hands.
So do you use online reviews as a major factor in deciding if you will watch a movie?

I don't. Well, sometimes, if the review is really, really bad. This movie was reviewed well, but I don't remember that having anything to do with it. I saw it mostly because of Tom Hanks and Stephen Spielberg.
I find it funny that a reviewer said it was 'not a major Spielberg film.'
The actors will be big factor for me when deciding to see a movie. But the reviews will still have to be okay for me to watch it in a theater. Otherwise I will wait for it to be rented online.
I choose more based on the advertising items. I don't remember what the trailer for this movie was like. I remember it highlighting the cheque fraud and that it was a true story.
Apparently, in the real story, Frank Abignale forged almost 3 million in cheques, but honestly, in today's money, that doesn't seem like that much.
Back then it would have been a lot.
They definitely took a creative license when making the movie.
I don't think I remember the bit about the French class. I remember it being Spanish, but then that's probably me being forgetful.
I don't either. I just remember him being a pilot and not being able to fly. And Tom Hanks character chasing Leo.
It been a long time since I last watched the film.
I'm a fan of Christopher Walken, but I did not care for him in this. He seemed like such a schlub.
Do you think it should be categorized as a biographic film, when it was clearly exaggerated?
Walken is a good actor but he is typecast for sure. It limits his roles.
All biopics are exageratted or manipulated. I don't think it was that much of a stretch.
That said, I remember thinking it was unfair that Frank got a deal to work with the FBI, like, you're such a good criminal that we're not going to punish you if you just told us how you did it.
I mean he could help them stop further crimes.
But yeah, its like he wins even after all that he did.
I suppose that's true. But I still feel like he escaped justice and we're supposed to be okay with it because he's a loveable rapscallion.
One thing I don't like about based-on-a-true--story movies in the title at the end that tells you what else happened to the person.
I kind of feel that, if it's part of the story, it should actually be part of the movie.
I can agree with that.
I think the movie made cheque fraud seem too easy.
At the time it was a little more easier.
But what did he do with all that money. He couldn't put it in a bank. Did he just carry it around in cash.
I suppose that's true.
It does seem like Frank did more good in the long run. Which I think kind of makes up for his crimes.
Anyway, nice talking with you.
Likewise.
